captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Hellblade 2: Senua&#39;s Saga is the sequel to 
Hellblade 1: Silly Sausage, and continues

the adventures of Senua, norse warrior lady 
and manic pixie dream girl without the pixie

part and only &quot;dream&quot; in the sense of constantly 
hallucinating wildly. Having gotten over her lover

being murdered by those northern bastards, Senua 
is resolved to stop beating herself up and take

her therapy in a more constructive direction 
by beating up some northern bastards instead,

so she stows away on a slave ship to their home 
turf, but because this game has a Tomb Raider

reboot level fetish for beating the absolute snot 
out of its heroine for the sake of grittiness,

she gets wrecked by a storm and winds up crawling 
up a bloodstained shingle beach in the rain,

although she shouldn&#39;t gripe, by Icelandic 
standards that would be classified as one of

the more touristy areas. The game plays much like 
God of War Ragnarok, even with the Scandi-weegee

setting aside, with its over the shoulder camera, 
press-forward-to-continue gameplay and enthusiasm

for narrow cave spelunking, but where Ragnarok 
used NPCs to ensure the constant flow of verbal

diarrhoea, Hellblade cuts out the middleman 
by leaving that to the voices in Senua&#39;s head.

The game recommends using headphones, but 
I&#39;m not sure I would. Unless you like the

sensation of two slightly posh British ladies 
whispering your shortcomings into both your

ears at every opportunity, once normally and 
once in a slightly ethereal way. Personally,

it reminds me too much of my family counselling 
sessions. Anyway, Senua&#39;s vague plan to rock up

to the headquarters of the slavers and demand to 
speak to the manager slips by the wayside when she

discovers that the island&#39;s various communities 
are being tormented by evil giants and she&#39;s

the only one who can kill them. If this were the 
first game I&#39;d suspect the giants were supposed to

represent something, like societal collapse 
or Senua&#39;s anxiety towards her upcoming job

interview or whatever, but Hellblade 2 subtracts 
some of the ambiguity from the narrative. I feel

like there was a lot in the first game you were 
supposed to assume was delusional or metaphorical,

but in the sequel Senua gathers some 
NPC helper friends and when she kills

a giant they&#39;re all like &quot;Fuck a duck! 
The weird starey lady just killed an

actual literal giant! We all saw it! Let&#39;s 
get her on the fucking lecture circuit!&quot;

I guess Senua could be hallucinating all of 
them, too, but that never fucking ends, does it,

maybe the whole game&#39;s a hallucination. Maybe 
Senua&#39;s actually a daydreaming data validation

clerk from Tunbridge Wells. So if you enjoyed 
that joke so much you now have to run off and

write it on a toilet wall somewhere, 
here&#39;s a quick summary of this review:

I didn&#39;t like Hellblade 2 much. As I say it&#39;s a 
little too much of a press-forward-to-continue

ghost train ride for my tastes, and the highest 
praise I could offer is that it&#39;s got some damned

impressive visuals. When it&#39;s not exclusively 
taking place in gloomy Icelandic caves,

I mean. It&#39;s going for that God of War single 
unbroken take no loading screens gimmick,

which just means they have to hide all the 
loading elsewhere while you&#39;re doing the narrow

cave squeeze thing and taking prolonged slow 
walks through very artfully crafted sod all.

But the battles with the giants are generally 
fucking spectacular, for what little gameplay

is involved and whatever&#39;s actually supposed 
to be happening, and a lot of effort went into

the facial animation. Which the game is very 
fucking keen to show off. The camera keeps

zooming really close into Senua&#39;s face while she 
massively overacts about whatever&#39;s giving her a

mental breakdown this time. Which made me very 
uncomfortable. Her teeth are so fucking big,

I kept thinking. It&#39;s like being cornered at 
a frat party by a sexually aggressive piano.

Hey everyone, Yahtzee just denigrated a female 
protagonist for looking weird. Guess we&#39;ve lost

another one to Andrew Tate. Oh piss off. I&#39;m 
mostly down on Senua for her decision-making

process. On something like three separate 
occasions we rock up to some eerily quiet

village or forest or other and the NPCs 
are all like &quot;We mustn&#39;t go in there,

it&#39;s full of danger and monsters and killer bees 
that specifically target women with large teeth

and names that start with S.&quot; And Senua will be 
like &quot;No actually it&#39;s suddenly vitally important

that I go in there. Someone might need help.&quot; 
She&#39;s certainly got what I once said was reboot

Lara Croft&#39;s problem: a bad case of the &quot;have 
tos.&quot; Where they keep reluctantly doing stupid

things because they say they &quot;have to&quot; with little 
further examination, which makes them come across

as lacking agency. I know she&#39;s supposed to be 
mentally ill, but maybe the reason I had to take

a break every couple of hours is &#39;cos I find it 
exhausting to watch a mentally disabled woman

blundering again and again into situations 
that a blind puffin could predict would lead

to her getting her face smashed against rocks 
some more. Sorry if that&#39;s condescending of

me. Obviously the neurodivergent should be free 
as anyone else to smash their face into rocks.

Speaking of which, at least the combat makes 
up for it. Oh sorry I misread that. Instead

of &quot;makes up for it&quot; I should have said &quot;sucks 
lukewarm catarrh through a human centipede.&quot; And

instead of &quot;at least&quot; I should have said &quot;fuck 
me up the stench zone.&quot; Every now and again

the game interrupts the slowly walking through 
rocky landscapes routine to go &quot;Oh shit we just

remembered we&#39;re a video game called &#39;Hellblade&#39; 
for fuck&#39;s sake&quot; and some combat happens,

and it always plays out exactly the same 
way. Angry dude walks in from offscreen,

tokenly backhands Senua across the mush and 
then the pair of you square off into a series

of extremely samey prebaked animations, until 
you press the right button enough times to win,

whereupon the bouncer lets another dude through 
the velvet rope and the whole sequence plays out

again until we&#39;ve worked our way through whatever 
arbitrary number of burly dudes were on the guest

list, and it feels like you&#39;re playing fucking 
Dragon&#39;s Lair with a glitch that makes the laser

disc skip. Then about halfway through you unlock a 
power which I like to call the &quot;I&#39;m bored of this

fight now&quot; button. Once you&#39;ve built up enough 
energy you just press it to do an unblockable

combo and almost always instantly win, just 
in time for the next backhand from offscreen.

I mean, if you wanna make a walking 
sim, nothing&#39;s stopping you, guys,

they&#39;re a bit polarising but at least we can 
have fun complaining about it, this half-baked

attempt at core combat just kills the pace. 
You know, part of what feels disingenuous

about Senua&#39;s apparent motive to help others 
is that we never see the fucking others. Like,

your NPC friends are all leaders of communities 
and enlist you to fight the giants that are

attacking those communities, but in almost every 
case they&#39;re like &quot;Yes, my villagers are under

threat. They&#39;re right over there. Behind that 
ridge. Where you can&#39;t see. You&#39;d like them,

probably.&quot; And then if you ever do see them it&#39;s 
only when they&#39;re running around screaming and

getting killed because the game jerked awake again 
and remembered it needed a combatty bit. And then

at the very end the final boss sequence dissolves 
into one of Senua&#39;s trademark hallucinatory

self-examination moments where she goes &quot;Can I be 
a leader to these people? You know, those people

right over there. Behind the hallucinatory fog. 
Where you can&#39;t see. You&#39;d like them, probably.&quot;

In final summary, the only two points that 
recommend Hellblade 2 for me are that it looks

nice and it isn&#39;t very long. The same advantages 
as a beginner-sized dildo with a bow on the end.

Oh, sorry, there&#39;s no
credits message this week.
Thanks for sticking around, though.

Oh, I guess you want one
of those call-to-action things?

Okay, uh, remember, if I
made you laugh at any point today,

then you have to like or subscribe or
consider joining the Patreon to support us.
It&#39;s the rule.

If you don&#39;t, you
go to prison or something.

You know, it&#39;s
like being in a live comedy

audience and not
laughing at jokes you find funny.

It raises the
question of why you&#39;re even there,

and the audio mixer
will think you&#39;re a dick.
